snippet: The exhibition “Bolt” at the Gallery for Russian Arts and Design in London gives vivid life to a ballet and to the way it exemplified a cultural moment in postrevolutionary Soviet Russia.
abstract: Roslyn Sulcas Critic's Notebook on exhibit Bolt, at the Gallery for Russian Art and Design in London, paying tribute to little-known 1931 ballet by Fyodor Lopukhov; ballet, which provides an alternate narrative of Russian dance history, was banned by Soviet government for its subversive content.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition “Bolt” at the Gallery for Russian Arts and Design in London gives vivid life to a ballet and to the way it exemplified a cultural moment in postrevolutionary Soviet Russia.

headline.print_headline: Revisiting a Soviet Ballet That Was Banned in 1931
headline.seo: ‘Bolt,’ at Gallery for Russian Arts and Design in London
headline.main: Revisiting a Soviet Ballet That Was Banned in 1931
